title: Will Saudi Arabia diplomatically recognize the State of Israel in 2021?
preds: Unless there are high-level secret meetings occurring, time is running out.

It is very unlikely that Saudi Arabia will recognize the State of Israel by the end of 2021. The two countries that normalized relations with Israel as part of the so-called 'Abraham Accords'--the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain--of 2020 did so for varying reasons. The UAE and Israel had informal relations dating back to the early 2010s, which were primarily focused on economic ties. Full normalization in 2020 allows for billions in trade across numerous economic sectors between the UAE and Israel.  Relations between Bahrain and Israel go back decades, with an official Israeli delegation visiting Bahrain in 1994. The Oslo Accord in 1993 allowed for the establishment of trade missions between Manama and Tel Aviv. However, the Arab boycott of Israel due to the 2001 al-Aqsa Intifada cooled relations. There are reports that Bahrain and Israel maintained a back-channel through their intelligence chiefs. Relations began to warm when Bahraini King Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa at the 2017 Arab Summit denounced the boycott of Israel and expressed a desire to establish tourism between Bahrain and Israel. The two countries also share a mutual apathy with Iran, especially as Bahrain has a Shi'a majority that rose up during the Arab Spring.  Sudan's normalization of relations with Israel was a quid pro quo. Following Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir's toppling by the military in the Spring of 2019, Khartoum was in the midst of establishing its first government since al-Bashir's 1993 takeover. Sudan was in dire need of economic assistance from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), but its listing on the U.S. State Department's state sponsors of terrorism list precluded Washington, which exercises tremendous power on the IMF Board of Governors, from endorsing IMF assistance. The Trump administration in 2020 made the normalization of ties with Israel as a condition of removing Sudan as a sponsor of terror and allowing for IMF assistance.  Saudi Arabia is a much different case. Even if the de facto ruler of the Kingdom, Crown Prince Muhamad bin Salman (MBS), sought to normalize relations with Israel, it is a very delicate issue in a country home to the two holiest sites in Islam. MBS for the past several years has sought to bring the Kingdom's conservative Wahhabi clerics under control. He has largely been successful in aligning the clerics with his ambitious social and economic reform efforts. Normalizing relations with Israel could lead to upheaval in the Kingdom. MBS currently enjoys informal relations with Israel through their intelligence services. Tel Aviv and Riyadh secretly deliberate on mutual regional security issues, especially as both consider Iran a significant foe. Put simply, MBS does not need to normalize relations with Israel. The main catalyst behind the normalization of relations between the UAE, Bahrain, and Sudan with Israel was the Trump administration. President Trump was desperate to announce a historic peace deal in the Middle East, with his first attempt to bring together Israel and Palestine having failed spectacularly. President Biden has not expressed an interest in committing U.S. diplomatic efforts to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian and Arab-Israeli conflicts, as each of his predecessors dating back to Clinton have. President Biden would likely seize an opportunity to bring the Israelis and Palestinians, or Israel and other Arab countries, together. However, the conditions for a peace agreement and the subsequent normalization of relations between Israel and other Arab states currently do not exist.
While, I remain bullish on this one, I also need to admit reality.  Downgrading a little.
I continue to be bullish on this possibility, even though the Biden Administration has turned away from Israel in their foreign policy focus.
time has passed and none of the relevant geopolitical events (Gaza, new coalition government) has made it more likely for this to resolve to "yes" so I am downgrading to reflect the consensus view.
Too little time left for this to happen, especially under new Israeli government.
If the King of Saudi Arabia is alive, the KSA will not recognize Israel.
Too little time left in 2021, no sign of any movement towards recognition.

Not out of the question, but it will depend a lot on whether the US keeps on making the same efforts as under the previous administration. Also, a revived Iran threat could bring Saudi and Israel closer.

Requires U.S. involvement to accomplish.  Simply not a priority for the Biden Administration.  Plus, there is a lot of instability in the Israeli government right now and not a priority in either county at the moment.
Very low probability due to the intensified conflict in Gaza in May 2021.
If the cease-fire continues to hold in this new coalition government of Israel comes to pass I believe this will resolve as yes
Adjusting downward to account for the impact of the ground conflict currently occurring in Israel and instability in the government.
Whatever odds there were for this happening before the war have dropped to zero now in my mind.

Going to zero with the outbreak of war between Hamas and Israel.  Given the enduring popularity of the Palestinian cause to every day Saudis, the disincentives for the Crown Prince seems to outweigh any upside incentives in the next seven months.
The resent news that Saudi Arabia and Iran have been in secret diplomatic discussions, facilitated by Iraq, greatly reduces the odds of Saudi Arabia recognizing Israel anytime soon.
Conflict with Hamas is probably going to slow down the recognition process

I remain fairly bullish on this forecast compared to other forecasters.  If the United States fails to rejoin the agreement with Iran, it make sense for the Biden Administration to turn their attention back to Israel.  The current situation and instability in Israel might necessitate the refocus sooner rather than later.  I do not believe that Saudi Arabia is far as people thinking from recognizing Israel.

Full reasoning: https://globalguessing.com/metaculus-mondays-vol12/#will-israel-and-saudi-arabia-normalize-relations The median prediction on Metaculus (https://www.metaculus.com/questions/6646/sa-israel-to-establish-diplomatic-relations/) is now 43%, down from 45% at our initial forecast in February of 21%. Here, the median is 4%. In our initial forecast (https://globalguessing.com/metaculus-mondays-vol3/) some of the factors we were considering were:
** Saudi Arabia's leadership dynamics
** The situation in Palestine
** Saudi government constraints
** Biden's political priorities While there hasn't necessarily been a change in any of those factors since our initial prediction, there are two other factors that we considered that are the impetus behind our update. First, two months have passed since our initial prediction which lowered the odds for this question slightly. The downward pressure effects of this factor are only slight because recent months have been occupied with an election and COVID vaccinations, making the time remaining slightly more irrelevant. Next, we considered a recent report that Saudi Foreign Minister Faisal bin Farhan said normalizing ties with Israel would bring ‘tremendous benefits’ to the Middle East. At the same time, however, the foreign minister also said that any change in relations would be predicated on a shift in the Israeli-Palestine situation. However, given a 56% median likelihood on Metaculus (https://www.metaculus.com/questions/6920/will-israel-hold-a-second-election-in-2021/) and $.53 price on Predict It (https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/7197/Will-Israel-hold-a-second-national-election-for-Knesset-in-2021) for a second national election in 2021, this signal is also minor. We gave the positive effects of this report at 1%, with a net effect of both new factors at -1%. This puts our updated forecast at 20% chance that Israel and Saudi Arabia normalize relations before 2022.
downgrading to reflect the passage of time

Say what you will about the Trump Administration, but the diplomatic break through for Israeli and increased Middle East security through the recognition of Israel by other Middle Eastern countries was an innovation move.  Bahrain's recognition of Israel opened the door to Saudi Arabia recognizing Israel in the future, but Bahrain would have never recognized Israel without some approval from Saudi Arabia.  However, the Biden Administration has prioritized Iran over other areas of the Middle East.  Efforts to support Israel in the region at this time would most likely undermine negotiations with Iran, especially after the most recent espionage incident.  A factor that is hard to account for is the generations of tension between Iran and Saudi Arabia.  How supportive is Saudi Arabia of the U.S. reentering the nuclear agreement with Iran?  If recognition occurred this year it would be without, or at least with limited, involvement of the United States.
They just said this hinges on a Palestinian state and there is not a lot of movement given the current election gridlock.
They wont.  It is to politically risky if Israel doesn't solve the Palestinian crisis.

Saudi and Qatar have both declared against normalization... overt recognition becomes harder to gain, even if it is useful for all players opposed to Iran

While the JPost article linked estimates normalization to occur within 1 year (i.e., in 2021), I am skeptical because the Biden Administration will be very unlikely to make as strong concessions as Trump did (e.g. affirming Moroccan sovereignty over Western Sahara). However Israel and Saudi Arabia clearly have aligned interests against Iran, and formal recognition of that fact may come in handy, e.g., if the US re-enters the JCPOA. (https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1935-before-1-january-2022-will-the-u-s-officially-rejoin-the-jcpoa). I gave that 1/3 odds; I think the odds here are longer but perhaps not quite as much as the crowd's consensus.
Not likely, unless Iran develops a nuke bomb before then

The Biden administration has signaled it does not have an overriding interest in dealing with the current Israeli government, which allied itself tightly with the previous president and continues to openly seek to frustrate Biden’s attempts to resuscitate the JCPOA.  Biden’s key aides for the ME say he has no interest in seeking a grand Middle East peace deal, which almost all presidents have sought since Nixon.  If Biden is not motivated to help the Israelis in pushing the Saudis to normalize relations, it is hard to see how this would happen in the time frame of the question.  My original forecast outlined my reasoning for assessing that the Saudis will go slowly, absent U.S. pressure. Against my reasoning: “my enemy’s enemy is my friend.”  Both Israel and the Saudis fear a nuclear Iran.  Depending on the terms of the new JCPOA, if it happens, the two countries may have increased incentive to align to balance Iran if they fear the deal will threaten their security.
Odds are slim, there is more strengthening of the diplomacy before acknowledgement can occur.

Saudi normalization with Israel is definitely possible, but it remains questionable whether this will actually occur in 2021. There are a couple of variables that need to be considered. Historically, there have definitely been tensions and disputes between Saudi Arabia and Israel, but there have also been friendly relations and joint efforts between the two, indicating the possibility of official diplomatic recognition. Israel and Saudi Arabia, two of the most important allies for the US in the Middle East, share common interests that they have promoted in a discreet manner as well as share common enemies, such as Iraq and Iran. Though Saudi Arabia has been highly critical of Israel, it has never done anything to threaten it, instead opting for a mediator role to promote a peaceful resolution to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. In December 2020, Saudi Arabian Foreign Minister Prince Faisal bin Farhan stated that Saudi Arabia is open to full normalization with Israel, but it rests on the condition of Palestinian statehood, believing that establishing a Palestinian state will deliver true peace in the region. Its foremost goal is getting Israelis and Palestinians back to the negotiating table and drafting a Palestinian-Israeli peace plan, so I think this is a key factor to consider when debating whether Saudi Arabia will diplomatically recognize Israel in 2021. Now that several Arab states formally recognize Israel, with the UAE, Bahrain, Morocco, and Sudan normalizing relations with Israel in 2020 through US-brokered deals, Saudi Arabia has stated that it will not follow their lead, despite its clandestine ties to the Jewish state. However, this might change as the US throws their support behind Saudi-Israeli relations as well as a two-state solution. Israeli PM Netanyahu and Prince Mohammed bin Salman allegedly met in secret in November 2020, discussing several issues, such as how to coordinate moves if the Biden administration rejoins the Iranian Nuclear Deal, but they reached no substantial agreements. This indicates a willingness to collaborate in furtherance of geopolitical interests. And though Saudi Arabia has maintained that it will not establish diplomatic relations with Israel without a resolution to the Palestinian issue, the Saudi government has been pushing to change Saudi public opinion about Jews and to increase outreach to Jewish communities, especially to notable Jewish figures. Taking all of this into consideration, I do not see Saudi Arabia formally establishing diplomatic relations with Israel unless there are some efforts made by Israel to establish Palestinian statehood or to at least negotiate and draft a peace plan with the Palestinians. Saudi Arabia has placed its support behind the Palestinian people for so long that it is highly unlikely that it abandons the Palestinians to establish formal ties with Israel. However, with the new Biden administration restoring relations with the Palestinians, renewing aid to Palestinian refugees, and publicly announcing its support for a two-state solution, we might see some incentives implemented to encourage negotiations between Israel and Palestine. Israel has been historically opposed to a two-state solution (obviously), but as Israel suspended its plans to annex the West Bank in exchange for establishing full diplomatic relations with the UAE, we could see a similar compromise made by Israel in order to establish advantageous relations with Saudi Arabia. This could be impeded depending on the Biden administration’s approach to relations with Saudi Arabia, as it has been reported that Biden has broken with Trump’s approach, stating that the US would hold Saudi Arabia accountable for human rights abuses; however, Israel has warned the US that pressuring Middle Eastern allies on issues related to human rights could jeopardize Israeli relations with the Arab countries and indirectly strengthen Iran. Though it is important to the US that its allies align with its values, I think that the Biden administration might temporarily overlook Saudi Arabia’s human rights abuses (if they do not worsen) in order to continue to promote Middle Eastern stability, keep Iran under check, and encourage positive relations between Israel and Arab countries. If we were to see Saudi Arabia diplomatically recognize Israel in 2021, I predict it will be in a US-brokered deal in which Israel agrees to engage in negotiations with the Palestinians in return for formal recognition by Saudi Arabia. I think it is more likely that this will happen in 2022 after the Biden administration more fully establishes itself and COVID-19 (hopefully) is no longer a primary concern, but it is still possible we will see this happen in 2021, which is why I am giving a 30% chance of occurrence.
Biden or the Saudis seem to be chasing it

With the Biden Administration ending arms deals with Saudi Arabia and also focusing less diplomatic energy on Israel, it is unlikely that the Saudis will move closer to normalizing relations with them, as they stand little to gain from it while potentially loosing the support/confidence of their other Muslim allies.

It seems unlikely;  the new US administration will not be so easily pleased with small gestures and with support ended for the Yemen campaign such a move offers little to Saudi within the timeframe. It will withhold recognition until there is more to be gained from it.
All I know is that it is a non-zero chance.

Seems a long shot at this stage, but a year is a long time. It will be interesting to see if there is a positive impact of recognition for some of the other states that took the step in 2020. If MBS sees benefits, it is possible. Saudi-Israeli relations are improving and the 'the enemy of my enemy is my friend' philosophy suggests MBS may take this step if he deems Iran a bigger threat. If the nuclear deal is not resurrected and Iran's program is stepped up, it may become more likely.

As far as I can tell the only reason Saudi Arabia would have for recognizing Israel right now would be in order to mend the relationship with the US and the new Biden administration (1), however it just seems like too small of a gesture, since MBS knows much of the content of Biden's strategy on foreign affairs, e.g. his stance on human rights and democracy. It would be possible to use this in a negotiation however. It could be that Biden and MBS would find themselves in a negotiation about the stance on Iran, and MBS could use neutralisation of the relationship with Israel as leverage. It does seem though, that MBS wants a closer relationship with Israel as they have probably had their first meeting. At the moment it seems it is possible to increase bilateral trade and work together against the common enemy, Iran, without neutralising the relationship, which is something King Salomon is strongly against (2). It appears likely that the relationship will be strengthened and eventually lead to a diplomatic recognition, but other than the fact that other countries have recently done so, it seems unlikely that Saudi Arabia would act now. Especially considering that the relationship is still strongly tainted due to the situation in Palestine, and a senior Saudi prince expressed in December that to them Netanyahu's government was "the last of the Western colonizing powers in the Middle East." (3) When it comes to other countries such as the UAE, Bahrain and Sudan recognizing Israel, like someone else wrote, it seems likely that MBS would wait and see what the outcome of this recognition will be. How will the people react and will it have positive benefits like an increase in trade. Finally, given everything above and therefore still quite a thin incentive to act now, the fact that only 6% of the Saudi population would support a diplomatic recognition of Israel (4) will at least slow the process. There is a beacon of hope in the same statistics though. 29% either did not answer or answered that they did not know whether they would support a diplomatic recognition of Israel. This could be an indication that people are torn or that they do not care too much. 1: https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2020/11/25/saudi-israeli-relations-the-curious-case-of-a-neom-meeting-denied/

The major issue here is the realpolitik of forging a common front by combing the Arab states against the enemy of Iran with its proxy armies and potential nuclear arsenal.
The UAE and Bahrain, particularly, will have probably be given the nod by Saudi Arabia to allow diplomatic relations with Israel, that indicates a long-term view to the same.
Holding back this is the fact that Saudi Arabia is the custodian of Mecca and Medina and will be cautious of Turkey or Iran wanting to wrest this crown from them.
The Saudi populace has been the recipient of 70 years of anti-Israel rhetoric and some studies shown that  80% would be against a full normalisation, which indicates a progressive, incremental move towards any rapprochement. 
Another issue that will pause the process are the internal politics of the Royal House of Saud and the opinions of the older generation, Prince Turki bin Faisal for example and its ambivalence towards Israel and concern over the Palestinian people.  The young Crown prince, MBS may wish to proceed but must stay respectful to the elders.
Therefore, Saudi Arabia may one day diplomatically recognise Israel, but not yet. https://www.spectator.co.uk/article/could-an-israeli-saudi-peace-deal-be-imminent-  https://www.bloombergquint.com/gadfly/saudi-arabia-is-in-no-rush-to-recognize-israel  https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/saudi-arabia-israel-prince-turki-faisal-colonising-power-bahrain
Too much history; too much uncertainty; and Trump is gone so less impetus for last minute deals.  There would need to be a change in the ruling family first and that is unlikely.

The crown prince might make a surprising move, especially if there's a sudden international crisis, but the chance is small considering how deeply the Saudi elite identify as protectors of the holy places, etc.
While there is momentum for recognition, what's in this for Saudi Arabia? I don't see what it is at the moment.

He's 85, so plausible that could happen this year, but even if it did you'd imagine there would be a period of consolidation before any dramatic shifts in foreign policy are made.

Underlying issues in the Middle East:
Iran vs Saudi Arabia vs Turkey Oil will decline in importance, leaving the Petrodollar dependant countries less wealthy and facing turbulence AND facing a decline in importance to the US and world economy... This will not happen overnight, but it is inevitable.. technology marches on, global warming does too..  Israel, regardless of the Palestinian question,  remains a factor in the power rivalry in the Middle East (Iran Saudi Turkey) The 4 countries that made Peace with Israel did so for various selfish interests, lubricated by US (Trump/Kushner) pressure. It was also a gift to Netanyahu. The precedent has been set, even if the Biden administration will alter the emphasis.
*****
The Saudis have all that to contend with, along with their own internal pressures, and the obvious appearance of abandonment of the Palestinians.. Besides the economic interaction, The Saudis gain overt cooperation against Iran, if they recognize Israel. I think it is inevitable that they will.. probably later in the year.

Inside case: The Saudi royal family’s rule is both absolute yet precarious in a Kingdom almost entirely dependent on oil revenue, which is in secular decline, to buy off the citizenry and ultra-conservative clerical leaders.  Saudi public opinion strongly supports the Palestinian cause and strongly opposes recognition of Israel.[1]. Saudi leaders, as protectors of the most important sites in Islam, are especially fearful of a Wahhabi backlash by recognizing Israel.  Consequently, they have moved slowly, methodically, and cautiously in their relations with Israel.  It is easy to see how the Saudi Royal family would wish to wait and see and things work out for their clients, the Bahrainis, who just normalized relations, before doing it themselves. Outside case: The Biden administration has had strong words and signaled a clear break from the previous administration, referring to the Kingdom as a “pariah” regime.[2]  The Saudis realize they need to flip the script of bad press that they have in the U.S right now due to the disastrous proxy war in Yemen, the grisly murder of Washington Post contributor and U.S. legal resident Jamal Khashoggi[3], persecution of women’s rights advocates, and lingering questions over Saudi complicity in 9/11. Nonetheless, the Saudis realize that a one time ceremony would do nothing to alleviate all the problems they confront in a skeptical Biden.  They would want to leverage recognition of Israel in return for substantial assurances for their core security interests.  That will take time to negotiate with the new Biden administration, which is currently reviewing its Middle East policy.  In the meantime the Saudis will be waiting to see what happens to Biden domestically.  If he turns out to be a weak president who loses the House in 2022, why rush to make preemptive peace offerings to him, the Crown Peace may possibly be thinking. Saudi Arabia is competing with Iran to be the leader of the Muslim world and recognizing Israel would undermine this objective. The status quo of Israel and Saudi Arabia working together discreetly is successful and there is not much to be gained by altering it for Saudi Arabia. Additionally, Israel's decision to continue building new West Bank settlements has been met with condemnation by Saudi Arabia further decreasing the chance of diplomatic recognition. (https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20210113-saudi-condemns-israel-decision-to-build-800-new-illegal-settlement-units/) There is a lot of time left in the year so it is possible that Saudi Arabia will diplomatically recognize Israel but as of right now it is unlikely.

Nothing to gain, a lot to loose.
